conclusion: To determine whether the distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is greater than or less than 100 meters, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph provided.
The graph shows the velocity (v) of the skydiver over time (t). The x-axis represents time in seconds (t/s). The y-axis represents velocity in meters per second (m/s).
We are interested in the interval from 0 to 10 seconds.

premise: The distance fallen is the area under the velocity-time graph within the specified interval.
conclusion: The area under the curve from 0 to 10 seconds can be approximated by calculating the area of the trapezoid formed by the graph.
The graph shows that the velocity increases from 0 to 20 m/s over the first 10 seconds.
The shape of the graph from 0 to 10 seconds is a trapezoid with: One base (initial velocity) = 0 m/s, The other base (final velocity) = 20 m/s, Height (time interval) = 10 seconds.
The area A of a trapezoid is given by: A = 1/2 × (b1 + b2) × h where b1 and b2 are the lengths of the two parallel sides (bases), and h is the height.

premise: b1 = 0 m/s, b2 = 20 m/s, h = 10 seconds
The area under the curve from 0 to 10 seconds is 100 square units, which represents 100 meters.
conclusion: The distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is greater than 100 meters. This is because the actual curve is above the straight line connecting the points (0,0) and (10,20), indicating that the skydiver's velocity increases more rapidly than a linear increase, thus covering more distance.
